Award.AwardTitle: Studies in the Climate Dynamics of Moist Processes
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project examines fundamental properties of tropical convective rainfall and its complex relationship to large-scale atmospheric conditions. The work builds on previous work by the same group which found that several important properties of tropical precipitation including frequency of occurrence, variance, and intensity, show simple behavior when treated as functions of bulk atmospheric water vapor content divided by a critical water vapor value related to temperature-dependent saturation specific humidity. The work is divided into four topics: 1) Observational constraints on representations of moisture, convection, and their interactions; 2) distribution tails associated with transport processes and their implications, particularly for extreme precipitation events; 3) Issues in precipitation simulation, moist teleconnections and convective margins, and 4) Methods for parameter sensitivity estimation/optimization with a focus on precipitation processes in regional climate issues.

The behavior of convective precipitation in the tropics is of immense practical importance, as the source of moisture for the large portion of the world's population residing in the tropics. Yet despite its importance the nature of tropical convection remains mysterious, as convective rainfall is governed by complex interactions between large-scale atmospheric conditions and the properties of small-scale convective clouds. Research conducted here seeks to improve understanding of tropical convection and its representation in weather and climate models, and such improvements have great potential benefit for decision makers confronted with the impacts of tropical climate variability (including El Nino events) and tropical climate change.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Among the most important processes in climate and extreme weather events are those involving atmospheric moisture and precipitation. Climate and weather models can reproduce basic aspects of these moist processes, but there are many challenges in fully understanding these processes in observations and improving the accuracy of how they are represented in computer models. One of the reasons is that part of the dynamics determining rainfall occurs at small spatial and time scales, for instance, the few-kilometer scale of intense convective updrafts and downdrafts in thunderstorms, or the time it takes a squall line or a front to pass a particular region. However, the climate effects involve interactions with very large scales, such as the thousands of kilometers traveled by atmospheric waves that communicate the effects of El Niño to surrounding regions. The large-scale waves and circulation both affect and are affected by the statistics of the small scales. Furthermore, even when a climate model approximately captures the results of this interaction, there are so many processes involved that it requires substantial theoretical work to unravel the causal chain and to devise means of improving the model. This project contributes to this in several ways. New observational diagnostics that more directly show how small-scale precipitation processes relate to larger-scale climate fields have been used to evaluate the Community Earth System Model (CESM), one of the main US climate simulation computational models. The results suggest that this model does reasonably well at reproducing the observed precipitation-temperature-moisture relationship at fast time scales. Isolating the part of the model that represents deep convection (i.e., thunderstorm-like precipitation processes), it was shown that inclusion of turbulent processes that cause convective plumes to interact with moisture in the lower free troposphere is very important to accurate simulation of precipitation onset. Related work contributed to understanding how probability distributions of precipitation and water vapor interact with representations of the small-scale processes. The parameters that control these small-scale processes in climate models can impact the simulation at the large-scale — methods were developed for more efficiently evaluating simulations against observations as a function of multiple parameters.

With this background at the process level, climate models were also evaluated for their simulations of precipitation change under El Niño natural variability, and for projections of regional precipitation change under global warming. In a collection of climate model simulations from modeling groups worldwide, known as the Coupled Model Intercomparison Project Phase 5, the remote impacts of El Niño on precipitation were reasonably well simulated in comparison to observations at large-scales, although details at smaller scales tended to differ. The relationship between increases in the Eastern Pacific jetstream near the US West Coast during El Niño and California rainfall was also reasonably reproduced in the models. A similar relationship between changes in the jetstream in this region and changes US West Coast rainfall under global warming was identified as a factor that should be taken into account in projections of climate change impacts on the region. Mechanisms for El Niño impacts in far the Western Pacific were also elucidated. Results from this project have been cited in the Fifth Assessment Report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, and considered by California water resource managers.
